instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2018 with possible CPU damage?
threads.message:
This board came in with extensive liquid damage in the USB-C, backlight, and <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> areas. After clean-up I replaced <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> and a few other corroded components. PPBUS was shorted to ground and I found <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, one of the CPU power chips, shorted; replacing it removed the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>.

Now, I get 20V on USB-C drawing 0.51A, PPBUS is 12.6V, and I have SSD and G3S rails. But no startup. DFU Restore proceeded to the padlock symbol, but the target computer showed no signs of life other than trackpad clicking.

What’s the best way to troubleshoot whether the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> has damaged the CPU, before I spend a lot of time fixing other issues on this board such as LCD backlight?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2018 with possible CPU damage?
threads.message:
Very likely dead CPU; overvoltage from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> destroyed it.
Compare ohm resistance to ground on the CPU coils with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2018 with possible CPU damage?
threads.message: The resistances on the CPU coils match a good board pretty well (3-4 Ω), that's why I haven't given up on this board. I also get 0.9V on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, similar to the 0.8V on a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2018 with possible CPU damage?
threads.message:
Failing CPU power supplies many times end with dead CPU.
Even no short on its coils, doesn't mean CPU has survived.
After 10-15s, core voltage should drop from 0.8V; compare its behavior in time with good board.

There is no reason to go for backlight, if no USB activity, nor image at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2018 with possible CPU damage?
threads.message: Yes, I see a drop in Vcore on a good board after 10s, but not on this board. Ok, goodbye CPU.
